content: You are a English teacher. You are going to help me express myself more fluently and idiomatically, and you will correct all my grammar mistakes and improper use of words.
Ask me a question.
What are some of your hobbies and interests?

I like playing snowboard, I go to play snowboard with my wife every end of the year. I hope I can go more frequently, but I live in a place where it doesn't snow in winter, and I don't have much vacations.

Great! It's always fun to have a hobby that you can share with your loved ones. In terms of grammar, the phrase "every end of the year" should be corrected to "at the end of the year" or "every year-end".Also, instead of saying "I don't have much vacations", it would be more natural to say "I don't have much vacation time" or "I don't have many opportunities to take vacations".
Help me change my answer become more idiomatical.

Sure! Here's one way you could make your answer more idiomatic:

"I'm an avid snowboarder, and every year I make it a point to hit the slopes with my wife. Unfortunately, where I live, we don't get much snow in the winter, so we have to make the most of our limited vacation time. I wish we could go snowboarding more often, but for now, we'll just have to enjoy our yearly trips." 

This version incorporates some informal language, such as "hit the slopes" (meaning to go snowboarding) and "make the most of" (meaning to take advantage of a limited opportunity). It also uses the phrase "limited vacation time," which is a more natural way to express the idea that you aren't able to take many vacations.
Ask me another question.
What do you like to do in your free time besides snowboarding?

I take most of my free time do workout when I cannot go snowboarding. I have to sit before computer for whole day because of my job, so I hope I can move my body after work to help me keep healthy and fit.

That's great that you prioritize your health outside of work. Here's how I would make some small grammatical corrections and changes to make your response more idiomatic:

"I spend most of my free time exercising, especially when I can't go snowboarding. Since my job requires me to sit at a computer all day, it's important for me to stay active and keep my body healthy. I've found that working out after work is a great way to destress and stay fit." 

This version uses the phrase "destress" (meaning to reduce stress) and changes "do workout" to "exercising" for smoother word flow. It also changes "when I cannot go snowboarding" to "especially when I can't go snowboarding" for clearer emphasis.
OK, ask me another question.
Sure! What's your favorite type of music, and why do you enjoy it?
My favorite sony is 'wake me up' by avicii, I don't know what type of this sony is, but I am sure that's my favorite.

Great choice! "Wake Me Up" is actually categorized as a dance-pop/folktronica song. Here's how to make your response more idiomatic and grammatically correct:

"My favorite song is 'Wake Me Up' by Avicii. I'm not sure what genre it falls under, but it's definitely my favorite. I love the catchy beat and the uplifting lyrics. It always puts me in a good mood!" 

This version simply corrects a few grammar mistakes (such as "sony" to "song" and "that's my favorite" to "it's my favorite") and adds in some more natural language (such as "catchy beat" and "uplifting lyrics"). You also don't have to know the exact genre of music - it's okay to just say that you're not sure.
I hope you use the simple words but still using idiomatical conjunction and sentences

Of course, I'll do my best to use everyday language while still incorporating idiomatic expressions! 

Can you tell me about a memorable vacation you took and what made it memorable?

Sure, the most memorable experience I ever have is that the first I went to France for snowboarding. The idea was occured to my mind just one week before I went to apply my France visa, and ed a journy by myself alone. That is how I learned to snowboard and I love it immediately. The sightseeingof 霞慕尼 is alos very attractive.

Great, here's how you can make your response more idiomatic and grammatically correct:

"The most memorable experience I've had was the first time I went snowboarding in France. The idea came to me just one week before I applied for my visa, and I decided to embark on the journey alone. It was during that trip that I learned how to snowboard, and I fell in love with it immediately. The sights and scenery of Chamonix (pronounced "sha-moh-nee") were also breathtaking and made the trip even more unforgettable."

This version uses more descriptive language to convey your experience, such as "breathtaking" for describing the sights of Chamonix. It also corrects some grammar errors, such as "occur to my mind" to "came to me" and "ed a journy" to "embarked on the journey". Lastly, it changes "霞慕尼" to "Chamonix," which is the standard English spelling of the French ski resort.
Good, next question.
What's something you're passionate about, and why are you passionate about it?

Believe it or not, I am really absorbed in programming. We can say modern society are built on the programming technology, and I was attracted by the ability that can help me implement the function that i need in daily life. Furthermore, after I accessed to the artificial intelligence, it's mystery and amazing performance also make me want to know more.

That's really interesting! Here's how you can make some small corrections and improvements to make your response more idiomatic:

"Believe it or not, I'm really passionate about programming. It's amazing to see how much of modern society is built on technology that programmers create. I love being able to use programming to create functions that I need in my daily life, and it's even more exciting now that I've started to learn about artificial intelligence. The mystery and amazing performance of AI have only fueled my interest in programming even more."

This version changes "absorbed in" to "passionate about" for clearer emphasis, and also rephrases parts of the response to make it more idiomatic. For example, using "amazing" and "exciting" to describe programming, and changing "accessed to" to "started to learn about".
Then, merge all answers above to a self-statment, the content must be fluent, idiomatic, and easy-understanding.

Certainly, here's an example of how you could merge your previous responses into a fluent, idiomatic self-statement:

"I'm passionate about several things, including snowboarding, exercise, music, and programming. I love to hit the slopes each year and have even traveled to France for snowboarding. When I'm not snowboarding, I spend my free time exercising to stay healthy and destress from my job as a computer scientist. One of my favorite songs is 'Wake Me Up' by Avicii - the catchy beat and uplifting lyrics always put me in a good mood! But above all, I'm really passionate about programming. The ability to use technology to create functions that I need in my daily life is fascinating to me, and I'm particularly intrigued by the mystery and amazing performance of artificial intelligence. I love how much of modern society is based on technology created by programmers, and it's exciting to think about how programming will continue to shape our world in the future." 

This version smoothly combines all of your previous responses while maintaining clarity and incorporating idiomatic language. I hope this helps!

Absolutely! Snowboarding is a physically demanding sport - how do you stay in shape and prepare for snowboarding season?

Now, I usually go to gym 6 days a week to keep my body active also build my shape. I do cross fit and weight training in term to let different part of my body can have enough time to rest. And I just have a log rest before snowboarding season, becasue you know, you can enjoy it fully when you are feeling tired.

That's great that you have a consistent workout routine to help you prepare for snowboarding season! Here's how you can make some small corrections and improvements to make your response more fluent and idiomatic:

"To prepare for snowboarding season, I usually go to the gym six days a week to keep my body in shape and active. I do crossfit and weight training to target different parts of my body, making sure that each part has enough time to rest. Right before the snowboarding season, I make sure to take some time to rest and recover, so that I'm not too tired to fully enjoy the experience." 

This version simplifies the phrasing and clarifies the importance of rest in preparing for snowboarding season. It also uses "consistent workout routine" to describe your gym schedule, which is a more natural way to refer to your exercise habits.
How to rephrase these words more close to daily speaking?

Sure, here's a rephrased version with more casual language:

"To get ready for snowboarding season, I hit up the gym six days a week where I do a mix of crossfit and weight training to stay in shape and keep my body active. I try to give each part of my body enough rest between workouts so that I don't get too sore. And right before the snowboarding season, I make sure to take a break so that I'm not too tired to have a good time on the slopes." 

This version uses more common, everyday language, such as "hit up the gym" and "get too sore," while still conveying the same message as before.
